results.title: Godard Taught Me How to Watch Cinema, Even as He Kept Reinventing It
results.abstract: Jean-Luc Godard was a prophet of film’s future as an art form, layering images and sound that the body could sink into and the mind could puzzle through.

multimedia.caption: Isabelle Huppert in “Every Man for Himself,” Jean-Luc Godard’s 1980 return to form.
Isabelle Huppert in “Every Man for Himself,” Jean-Luc Godard’s 1980 return to form.
Isabelle Huppert in “Every Man for Himself,” Jean-Luc Godard’s 1980 return to form.

results.title: Jean-Luc Godard, 91, Is Dead; Bold Director Shaped French New Wave
results.abstract: The Franco-Swiss filmmaker and provocateur radically rethought motion pictures and left a lasting influence on the medium.
results.byline: By Dave Kehr and Jonathan Kandell

multimedia.caption: Jean-Luc Godard in 1964. “I have always confused cinema with life,” he said. “To me life is just part of films.”
Jean-Luc Godard in 1964. “I have always confused cinema with life,” he said. “To me life is just part of films.”
Jean-Luc Godard in 1964. “I have always confused cinema with life,” he said. “To me life is just part of films.”

results.title: 9 Great Godard Films to Stream Now
results.abstract: From the youthful New Wave excitement of “Breathless” to the experimental works of his old age, Godard changed cinema.

multimedia.caption: Jean Seberg and Jean-Paul Belmondo in the 1960 film “Breathless,” Jean-Luc Godard’s feature-length debut.
Jean Seberg and Jean-Paul Belmondo in the 1960 film “Breathless,” Jean-Luc Godard’s feature-length debut.

results.title: 159 Films, for Every Taste, Coming This Fall
results.abstract: From art house to hellhouse and back, here’s a select list of the most anticipated titles this season, including “The Fabelmans,” “White Noise” and more.

results.title: A Filmmaker Explores David Bowie’s Life and Finds Clarity About His Own
results.abstract: With the epic “Moonage Daydream,” Brett Morgen contended with a chameleonic star whose approach to living helped him refocus after a heart attack.

multimedia.caption: “Moonage Daydream” drew on archival footage from David Bowie’s estate, some of it rare and never broadcast before.
“Moonage Daydream” drew on archival footage from David Bowie’s estate, some of it rare and never broadcast before.
“Moonage Daydream” drew on archival footage from David Bowie’s estate, some of it rare and never broadcast before.

results.title: To Play an Anti-Gay Parent, Gabrielle Union Dug Deep for ‘The Inspection’
results.abstract: At the Toronto premiere, she spoke of playing a homophobic mother as “the challenge of a lifetime” because it represents everything she stands against in reality.

multimedia.caption: Gabrielle Union at the premiere of “The Inspection.” She was the director’s first choice for the part.

results.title: The No-Spoilers Guide to ‘Glass Onion,’ the ‘Knives Out’ Sequel
results.abstract: The Rian Johnson mystery delighted Toronto audiences. There was only one problem: How do you talk about it — any of it — without giving anything away?

results.title: In ‘The Fabelmans,’ Steven Spielberg Himself Is the Star
results.abstract: But it’s Michelle Williams who burns brightest in this film based on Spielberg’s childhood, which just premiered at the Toronto International Film Festival.

results.title: Remember ‘Avatar’? Neither Do We. Catch Up Before the Sequel Arrives.
results.abstract: After 13 years, James Cameron’s sequel, “Avatar: The Way of Water,” is finally opening in December. Here’s everything you need to know.

results.title: Opening Old Wounds as the Man Who Warned About the Holocaust
results.abstract: In the solo play “Remember This,” David Strathairn portrays Jan Karski, a witness to the Nazi genocide during World War II.
des_facet: Remember This: The Lesson of Jan Karski (Play)

multimedia.caption: “Do we impart horror upon our children? Or do we want to protect them?” David Strathairn asked recently, reflecting on the challenges of talking about the atrocities of the Holocaust.
multimedia.copyright: Emon Hassan for The New York Times

results.title: Marsha Hunt, Actress Turned Activist, Is Dead at 104
results.abstract: She seemed well on her way to stardom until her career was derailed by the Hollywood blacklist. She then turned her attention to social causes.

multimedia.caption: The actress Marsha Hunt in an undated photo. Early in her career, she was one of the busiest and most versatile actresses in Hollywood.

results.title: ‘About Fate’ Review: Love the One You’re With?

results.title: ‘Dos Estaciones’ Review: A Tequila Factory’s Story, Sip by Sip
results.abstract: A woman tries to keep her family business running in this film that employs dreamlike rhythms and documentary-style realism.

results.title: An Inscrutable Monarch, Endlessly Scrutinized Onstage and Onscreen
results.abstract: Queen Elizabeth II was portrayed in plays and highbrow films, in made-for-TV movies and broad comedies and, of course, in “The Crown.” Many sought to answer the question: What was she like?
per_facet: Elizabeth II, Queen of Great Britain

multimedia.caption: Many distinguished actors have taken on the role of Queen Elizabeth II over the years, including Helen Mirren in Stephen Frears’s 2006 film “The Queen.”
Many distinguished actors have taken on the role of Queen Elizabeth II over the years, including Helen Mirren in Stephen Frears’s 2006 film “The Queen.”

results.abstract: Two strangers explore the basement of their Detroit rental home in this gleefully twisty horror movie by Zach Cregger.

results.title: ‘The Woman King’ and Intimate Moments Amid Epic Action
results.abstract: The director Gina Prince-Bythewood is known for her attention to character, but she made this historic saga of female warriors on another scale altogether.

multimedia.caption: The more Gina Prince-Bythewood learned about the Agojie army, “the more I got excited about putting this incredible culture — and us — onscreen in a way that we haven’t been able to see ourselves.”
multimedia.copyright: Erik Carter for The New York Times
